'''Angela Strehli''' (born November 22, 1945, [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], [[Texas]], [[United States]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]]. She is also a [[Texas blues]] historian and impresario.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Richard Skelly |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/angela-strehli-mn0000044802/biography |title=Angela Strehli | Biography |publisher=AllMusic  |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> Despite a sporadic [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] career, Strehli spends time each year performing in [[Europe]], the [[United States|US]] and [[Canada]].<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
In the early 1960s, Strehli learned the [[harmonica]] and [[bass guitar]] before becoming a vocalist.<ref name="AMG"/> In 1966 she visited [[Chicago]], and attended [[concert]]s given by [[Howlin' Wolf]], [[Muddy Waters]] and [[Buddy Guy]]. In her final university year, Strehli and Lewis Cowdrey formed the Fabulous Rockets. Strehli then sang as a [[backing vocalist]] for James Polk and the Brothers and assisted with Storm, which had been formed by Cowdrey and [[Jimmie Vaughan]].<ref name="Tunegenie">[http://www.tunegenie.com/bio/MN0000044802/angela-strehli/ ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}}</ref>

In 1972, she was a founding member of Southern Feeling, along with [[W. C. Clark]] and [[Denny Freeman]]. Three years later Strehli became the stage manager and sound technician at [[Clifford Antone|Antone's]], a [[nightclub]] in Austin, Texas. By 1986, Strehli had recorded ''Stranger Blues'' ([[Extended play|EP]]) which help launch Antone's own [[record label]].<ref name="Tunegenie"/> Her debut [[album]] was ''Soul Shake'' (1987, Antone's Records), and she appeared on ''Dreams Come True'', with [[Lou Ann Barton]] and [[Marcia Ball]] (1990). Her own effort ''Blonde and Blue'' (1993, Rounder Records) assisted in building the [[Austin, Texas]] blues scene, alongside [[nightclub]] owner Clifford Antone, [[Kim Wilson]], [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]] and [[Jimmie Vaughan]].<ref name="AMG"/> In 1998, Strehli released ''Deja Blue'', and ''Blue Highway'' followed in 2005.<ref name="AMG"/>
 
Strehli has either recorded, toured or performed with [[Andy Santana]], [[Elvin Bishop]] and [[Pinetop Perkins]], and appeared at [[music festival|festivals]] including [[Notodden Blues Festival]], [[Long Beach Blues Festival]], [[Edmonton's Labatt Blues Festival]] and the [[San Francisco Blues Festival]]. In 2003, she recorded music for the [[tribute album]], ''[[Shout, Sister, Shout: A Tribute to Sister Rosetta Tharpe]]''.

Strehli is now based in [[San Francisco]].<ref name="AMG"/>

==Discography==
*''Soul Shake'' (1987) - Antone's
*''Dreams Come True'' (1990) - Antone's (with [[Lou Ann Barton]] and [[Marcia Ball]])
*''Blonde and Blue'' (1993) - [[Rounder Records|Rounder]]
*''Deja Blue'' (1998) - House of Blues 
*''Blue Highway'' (2005) - M.C. Records<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/angela-strehli-mn0000044802/discography |title=Angela Strehli | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1945-11-22 |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
